Posts.Content: Well, first post surgery post, had the catheter removed today which is nice, on the other hand, the pathology report has me at stage p3ta pN0. I'd be very interested in any input. I have a great doctor I think, but he is very abrupt and we were sort of left wondering what all this means. I can find online where this staging means the cancer is? was ? outside the prostate, but what does that mean, did he get it all? The report mentions angiolymphatic invasion, but not sure what that means or is indicative of. Finally, the report mentions that the extraprostatic extension was present along the right lobe along the lateral and posterior aspect. The doctor started out with "I got all the cancer" so that, negative margins and the Gleason staying at 3=4+7 seems good. My wife and are are at square one again and pretty pessimistic, this seems like not so good news.
Posts.Signature: BD 1962 Age at Diagnosis 54 Biopsy Diagnosed with PC Gleason 3+4 Mid March 2017 Perineural Invasion 3 out of 12 cores positive Bone Scan OK Early April 2017 Pre Op PSA history December 7, 2012 2.130 May 14, 2013 2.270 December 22, 2014 2.780 May 2, 2016 2.320 DaVinci Surgery 15 May 2017 Pathology Gleaseon 3+4=7 Extraprostatic extension: present along the right lobe along the lateral and posterior aspect. Perinural invasion: extensive Angiolymphatic invasion: single focus suggestive of angiolymphatic invasion Surgical margins of resection apex negative bladder neck negative peripheral negative Microscopic invasion of the bladder neck: not identified Seminal Vesicle invasion: not identified AJCC pathologc stage pT3a pN0 Four lymphnodes negative for metatastic carcinoma Cancer discovered during a DRE following urinary problems caused by kidney stone problems, otherwise I had no problems, thank goodness for kidney stones
Posts.Title: Not a great pathology report? Need an experienced eye please

Posts.Content: Will do on the standby Highlander, i'd be glad to post more details of the pathology report if it will help anyone interpret it. Roblee, you are correct on my typo, the report reads 3+4=7 which I do understand is great news, the rest of the story: Tumor type Prostatic Adenoccarcinoma. Acinar type Tumor comprises approximaely 15% of total tissue submitted Tumor location, left and right side, multiple foci from apex to base along the lateral and posterior aspect of the lobe. Extraprostatic extension: present along the right lobe along the lateral and posterior aspect. Perinural invasion: extensive Angiolymphatic invasion: single focus suggestive of angiolymphatic invasion Surgical margins of resection apex negative bladder neck negative peripheral negative Microscopic invasion of the bladder neck: not identified Seminal Vesicle invasion: not identified AJCC pathologc stage pT3a pN0 Four lymphnodes negative for metatastic carcinoma

Posts.Title: New Guy Here, Surgery on Monday

Posts.Content: Yes, many years as a helicopter pilot, been in 2 wars, looks & feels like I'm about to go into another. I think I figured out how to get some of the info you suggest posted, as for PSA, results were always nada up till the cancer was discovered, so, hopefully, I'll be able to post some low numbers after the surgery.

Posts.Title: New Guy Here, Surgery on Monday

Posts.Content: Well, I've been lurking on here for a couple of months after a Gleason 3+4 diagnosis, with perinueral involvement. Robotic surgery is on Monday. I've gleaned lots of good information on this site, so I thought I'd finally post before I take the plunge. I'm at the point where probably everybody is right now. Terrified about what they are going to find when they operate, sad for the loss of what has been up till now good potency, never had continence issues etc, but hopeful that they will get all the cancer & I can put this behind me after the recovery.

Posts.Content: Best of luck survivor61 & I wish you the same. I had the same experience with this forum, I'm very careful about such things, but this looks like a good one.
Posts.Signature: BD 1962 Age at Diagnosis 54 Biopsy Diagnosed with PC Gleason 3+4 Mid March 2017 Perineural Invasion 3 out of 12 cores positive Bone Scan OK Early April 2017 Pre Op PSA history December 7, 2012 2.130 May 14, 2013 2.270 December 22, 2014 2.780 May 2, 2016 2.320 DaVinci Surgery 15 May 2017 Pathology Gleaseon 3+4=7 Extraprostatic extension: present along the right lobe along the lateral and posterior aspect. Perinural invasion: extensive Angiolymphatic invasion: single focus suggestive of angiolymphatic invasion Surgical margins of resection apex negative bladder neck negative peripheral negative Microscopic invasion of the bladder neck: not identified Seminal Vesicle invasion: not identified AJCC pathologc stage pT3a pN0 Four lymphnodes negative for metatastic carcinoma Cancer discovered during a DRE following urinary problems caused by kidney stone problems, otherwise I had no problems, thank goodness for kidney stones

Posts.Content: Yes, many years as a helicopter pilot, been in 2 wars, looks & feels like I'm about to go into another. I think I figured out how to get some of the info you suggest posted, as for PSA, results were always nada up till the cancer was discovered, so, hopefully, I'll be able to post some low numbers after the surgery.

Posts.Title: Angiolymphatic Invasion question

Posts.Content: Hello all and thanks so much for all the support so far, this is a great forum. I posted earlier on about my pathology report, and now that I've had some time to get my head around it, at least a little bit, the only part that truly has me concerned is the "Angiolymhatic invasion present" part of the report. After much googling, I just can't come up with a lot of information. Is it the same thing as Lymphovascular Invasion or LVI? It's a little confusing as the lymph nodes that they took were apparently clear. Anyone had any experience with this? It's got me pretty worried? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Posts.Title: Angiolymphatic Invasion question

Posts.Content: Thanks MM, I know it took some work to find that, I appreciate your response, on the surface, it looks like this question is a "hot potato" that no one else waned to touch. My Doctor kind of danced around it too. My wife and I have decided to accelerate the process of talking to a MO about this so maybe we can get some straight talk out of him, as painful as that might be. For me, hope seems to be slipping quickly, so I'm trying to find a way to stay positive, and that is tough in the face of a lack of information. But again, I thank you.

Posts.Title: Angiolymphatic Invasion question

Posts.Content: My wife was recalling a part of a conversation she & I had with the surgeon who took out my prostate. I must have blocked it out! But I trust her, and what she remembers is him saying "It's not a matter of if your prostate cancer comes back, but when" Man! you better believer that has been rolling around in my mind lately! So given my stats (EPE and Lymphovascular Invasion being the standouts) What do you guys think, is that the reality? BTW, all 0.00 so far!

Posts.Title: Tough statement from my Doctor, Realistic?

Posts.Content: Thanks all, sage advice as usual, Michael F, we do indeed share similar stats, interestingly enough we both had relatively low PSA BEFORE the cancer was discovered. I'm learning to live with this, one day at a time. Bravehardon, I tend to agree, I think this guy is a gifted surgeon with terrible bedside manner, but on the whole, I'll settle for that for sure, way better than a crappy surgeon with great bedside manner. Frank and open discussion, that's one of the things I like so much about this forum, that and the fact that possibly those that come after us in this journey hopefully won't have to "break trail" as much, a noble cause all on it's own right there my friends.

Posts.Content: OK oh wise ones, the first big test is fast approaching. My question is, what should I do, within my control, to make sure the test is as accurate as possible? Anything I should or should not eat, drink, take or do leading up to the test? Thank you.

Posts.Title: Another New Guy question

Posts.Content: Creekrat, I've probably read all this advice or similar 100 times in the last 5 months & it's all very true & correct. But somehow, I, and I sense a lot of others, don't "get it till you live it" It is a slooooooooow process (and I'm nowhere near the end). Just keep telling your brother to keep with the patience when he gets frustrated with the inevitable spills drips & runs. And, at least for me, when I think I've got it, it jumps up and gets me when I least expect it. I've also tried to make the worry about my future with PC somewhat constructive, and every time I find myself worrying about the future, recurrence, or peeing my pants, I do kegals. At least I get something out of the anxiety! Working on that too. My timeline, 3 months, I could pretty much strain IF I thought about it in advance without incident, now at 5 months, dry at night, and mostly in the day, except a lot of "mystery spots" where I never knew when it happened, but I suspect it's mostly from impatience before stepping away from the toilet. I also saw some useful posts on here on getting all the urine out when using the bathroom, still working on that and maybe one of the more experienced guys on here can post links to that? I seem to remember the phrase "milking" perhaps you can search this forum on that, it seemed like pretty good advice. Also, for me personally, I'm fighting the battle between staying hydrated enough (never enough according to my doctor) and peeing every 5 minutes, but I suspect that's pretty normal too.
